title: Information Design and Learning-Based Control for Large-Scale Mobility Systems.
text:
Abstract: Modern mobility systems face persistent spatial supply-demand imbalances that affect the system efficiency and welfare. For human-driven platforms, the challenge lies in managing strategic agent behavior; for autonomous fleets, the bottleneck is the computational scalability of large-scale fleet control. This seminar presents two frameworks—grounded in information design and deep reinforcement learning—that address spatial resource allocation in these distinct paradigms.
First, we examine strategic information design in networks where agents strategically reposition to maximize their payoffs in face of demand shocks. Modeling this as a network game, we characterize optimal information disclosure mechanisms and establish that, in many practical settings, simple “monotone partitional” mechanisms are optimal for maximizing platform revenue and minimizing system costs. Second, we address the operational control of large-scale electric robo-taxi fleets, spanning ride matching, repositioning, and charging. To overcome the curse of dimensionality, we introduce Atomic Proximal Policy Optimization (Atomic-PPO), which decomposes the fleet dispatching problem into constant-dimension sequential assignments. We prove this decomposition is without loss of optimality for a wide variety of stochastic network control problems.
Finally, we validate both frameworks using real-world data from the New York City for-hire vehicle market. Our findings illustrate how strategic signaling with scalable control policies significantly enhances the efficiency and sustainability of urban mobility systems.

title: Ever Since Allais and Ellsberg
text:
Abstract: The Allais critique of expected utility theory (EUT) has led to the development of theories of choice under risk that relax the independence axiom, but which adhere to the conventional axioms of ordering and monotonicity. Unlike many existing laboratory experiments designed to test independence, our experiment systematically tests the entire set of axioms, providing much richer evidence against which EUT can be judged. Our within-subjects analysis is nonparametric, using only information about revealed preference relations in the individual-level data. For most subjects, we find that departures from independence are statistically significant but minor relative to departures from ordering and/or monotonicity. We also extend the results in settings with risk (known probabilities) to settings with ambiguity (unknown probabilities) and also to time instead of risk tradeoffs.

title: Interdisciplinary Data Science (IDS) at UC Berkeley
text:
We are a group of faculty interested in strengthening interdisciplinary data science at UC Berkeley. Our faculty use the revolutionary changes in data collection, methods, and the emergence of new phenomena, to advance natural and social science disciplines in ways that lead to new areas of scholarship. Our unifying mission is to leverage data to address pressing questions with social and scientific impact.


We have the following Google Group mailing lists for communicating events and activities:

Students and Post-docs – students and post-docs are welcome to add themselves to this google group to learn about student events
IDS Faculty – faculty who are members of the IDS faculty group
Affiliated Faculty – related UC Berkeley faculty who wish to contribute to building the IDS community
General mailing list – general purpose mailing list open to the UC Berkeley community. Join by adding yourself to the google group to receive announcements of seminars and other events (groups listed above are automatically part of this mailing list!)
